title: "Eco-Friendly Plowing: Sustainable Farming with John Deere & Lemken"

tasks.task: Compare traditional plowing with conservation methods.
subtasks: Understand how traditional plowing turns over the soil completely.
Recognize the environmental impacts of traditional plowing, such as erosion and loss of topsoil.
Explain how conservation plowing minimizes soil disturbance.
Describe no-till farming as planting directly into previous crop residue.
List the benefits of no-till farming, including reduced soil erosion, improved water retention, and carbon sequestration.
Address challenges associated with no-till farming, such as weed control and potential increased herbicide use.
Define strip-till as tilling only narrow rows for planting.
Mention the benefits of strip-till, such as clean planting rows and faster soil warming.
Outline the process of implementing strip-till, including selecting row spacing and using a strip-till implement.

tasks.task: Describe the integration of cover crops in eco-friendly plowing.
subtasks: Explain the purpose of cover crops in preventing erosion during off-seasons.
Describe how cover crops add organic matter and nutrients when plowed under.
Detail the process of planting cover crops after the main harvest and options for integrating them into no-till planting.
Highlight the importance of regular soil testing for sustainable farming.
List components of soil testing, including nutrient levels, organic matter, pH, and soil structure.
Emphasize the role of soil microbial activity tests in understanding soil health.
Explain using soil test results to guide fertilizer and lime applications.
